THE CHAIRMAN: Thank you, sil'o
Now can we go back to the Japanese loan. I would like first to calIon Mr. Kheradjou.
MR .. KHERADJOU: Mr. Chairman, gentlemen, when the $40 I
I million loan for the expressway was presented here last March~ ! we reported that as far as the Japanese steel industry was concerned the Bank had ad vlsed them that, in the fut ure, it ~rould consider only very modest loans as part of a combined operation. At that time Kawasaki and Sumitomo had already discussed through their bankers, placement of their notes wtth inst Itut ional 1rlvestors in the United states $4 million to $5 million for Kawasaki and $5 million to $7.5 mIllion for Sumttomoe The raising of loans by the  ; Japanese private companies was never considered an easy task " ! but the students' demonstrations, which were interpreted by
i the .J
foreign investors as a threat to political stability in ! II Japan, upset the work of months of negotiations with U. S. ii "
:\ investors, just at the pOint where it seemed these would be I ! successfully concluded. In fact, discussions had gone so
far that the investors agreed not to withdraw from the deals but to await a calmer political atmosphere which was expected
to prevail after the general elections. The bankers could,
however, obtain a tentative promise, subject to the clearing
of the political atmosphere, for the placement of $4 million
of Kawasaki notes and, this annunt, only when the Bank agreed
to lend $6 million to make up the initially needed amount
for the project. Sumitomo, for which it was planned to raise !
'i $7-1/2 million, managed to place some $5 million of its notes
'with the same provision, and the Bank agreed to consider a
loan of 07 million. After the President's report was distriÂ­
, buted we were informed that purchasers have now been found
: for $5,8 million of Sumitomo notes which, with this loan, if
:' approved, and with the ~600,OOO 3-year loan to be borrowed
from I',lanufactures Trust, make the total amount of funds raised
by Sumitomo ~p13.4 million. The interest on the I'.'ianufactures
Trust loan has been reported as 6-1/2% in the President's
report but we have since learned that this rate has been under
negotiation and will be 5-3/4%.  16
The hard work and perseverance against odds shown by
. the officers of these companies in their pioneering \'lOrk of
raising loans abroad without involving Government credit may
, be considered another facet of the excellent management they
enjoy.
Since the Bank urged the Japanese steel industry to tap
, private capital markets abroad, quite a number of Japanese
companies have tried or made plans to raise funds on their
own. Kobe Steel Works, one of the companies for which the
Bank had made a loan of ;,~lO million in 1958, was fortunate
in obtaining ;i~30 million from the Prudential Insurance
Company of America in June just before the Toyko disturbances
had caused nervousness. v'le were glad to do all we could to
help Kobe carry out that operation. The loan l"hi ch was
guaranteed by a number of the largest private banks in Japan
wa.s for a term of 15 years with 7% interest.
Japan obviously needs foreign capital for its extraÂ­
ordinarily high pace of development, and Japanese private
companies are active in trying to attract this capital.
HOl'leVer, the difficulties encounter ed over the past year
showed two things: One, raising of capital by way of loan
is at least as difficult as it was thought by the Bank,
especially when some equity feature is not included; tvlO,
the direct or indirect support of the Bank for awhile yet
'1/' is considered of~reat importance by many investors for  17
'Japan to raise long-term capital. These two Bank loans are proposed for good projects of
high developmental priority and for two very well run
I companies with whom we have enjoyed excellent relations for , : some years. The servicing of these loans would obviously
present no problem either for the companies or for .Japan.
With these two loans total lending, since Mr. Black's
1957 visit to Japan when the active phase of our operations
in Japan began, would amount to ~271 million of which ~~140 million has been for steel, $101 million for power and $40 :, 'million for a highway. So even before the $300 million
lending program discussed by l':'ir. Black was exhausted, it was 'ifelt that the turnof fortune had made Japan's credit so good,
at least on any showing of economic growth and balance of
payments and reserves position, that a weaning process should
start and Bank loans should be used to help establish the
credit, both of the GoverlU'Tlent and of the private corporations,!
,in the private capital markets. This is one reason why
:iconsideration of a loan for the Japanese National Railways
was made conditional on a market operation for a Government
:project either prior to our loan or simultaneously. The
Railway Project, the New Tokaido Line, was presented to the Bank as the basis of a ~100 million loan nearly two years ago. As mentioned in our last loan presentation public transport has been a conspicuously neglected sector of the  18

MRo LIEFTINCK: Mr. Chairman, I particularly welcome
th1s new feature in the Bank lending applied in these two cases. I think it is very gratifying that the American market is being opened up for such borrowing, although one is inclined to give it some reflection w:~th respect to the present dollar problem. The amounts are small, so I don't think ~_t 1.5 var:.r important., The first question which has come to my mind when  26 2 studylng these two papers 1s this one. The Bank has made in

It appears to me that Japan should be rather selectlve

ClSS1.stance, aI'll:'! I think the Internal ~ondtttolls tn Japan

larly tn the public sector and the infrastructure sector,
and therefor'e I would like to ask whether the staff agrees

MR. .. tilLSON: Mro Chairman, I wonder 5.f I could ask a
question about the pr'ocurement policy in relation to each of
these two loans. In the first one, the Kawasaki loan, it says in paragraph 24 of your report that bids are limited to domeat 1c s uppl iers only where past experience has show!) that tt is clearly more advantageous for the company to
purchase the gooos in Japan. It could be argued that if it is clearly advantageous to place the orders in Japan that the foreign potential suppliers would equally be aware of thts circumstance and would not themselves put 1n bids tf
t,hey are invited to do sOo I am wondering really what is the reason in these cases for limiting domestic suppliers where  32
it is so clearly advantageous, and in these cases who it is that decides whether a particular bid is gotng to be put out to international tender or limited to domestic suppliers. I have another question, aleo on procuremento Again it is stated in your report, in paragraph 23, that the procureÂ­ ment of the imported goode is by international bidding, and i Ii d I see in paragraph 17 that the total foreign exchange cost for imports 1s $988 million. The proposed Bank loan is $7 million, which would cover most of the imported equipment. And again in the appraisal report, on page 9, paragraph 45, i it says that contracts ha ve alreaCly been placed on a comÂ­ i petltive basts, and the major pieces of equipment will have tal I
be imported, and fore ign orders have been placed through
international competitive biddingo
I am not clear whether the t"lhole of the Bank loan is

to be used for the purchase of domestic equipment, and in
the case of domest ic equipment ~lhat the pos it ion is about
international competitive bidding.
MR. THIBAUD: I think the answer to your last question is that in the case of Sumtt orno the whole loan is for imported, equipment. we canbnly cover part of the total foreign exchan~ requirements. In the case of Kawasaki., part of it is for imported equipment and part of it is to cover local currency expend1.tures. 8 Now, referring to the competitive bidding, they decide really if it is better to ask for foreign suppliers to bid, but we are very careful ana review their orders. We receive every three months a detail of the orders and the contracts , that they have placed, and we can know right away what are the goods that should be produced in Japan. For instance, there is no question they could produce a blast furnace " much cheaper than they could purchase it abroad, but if they want to put up a hot strip mill, which is a highly specialized! ! doc.repnme: Transcript of three hundred twenty ninth regular meeting of the Executive Directors of the Bank, held on Friday, December 16, 1960 : Japan - Third Kawasaki Project and second Sumitomo Project
doc.abstracts: This transcript, from the session of the Executive Directors of the International Bank on Reconstruction and Development held Friday, December 16, 1960, covers only the discussion on the approval of loan to Japan Development Bank for the Third Kawasaki Project and second Sumitomo Project.
